messageBody:
Actually, that hot key combination will run the test even when the file is
not in the editor at least in Eclipse 3.0M2. In my version though, the
hotkey combination is: Alt+R, S, 3.

If you really want to add a menu item to a popup menu you use the
org.eclipse.ui.popupMenus extension point. It has two "modes", one where
you add a menu item to a specific popup menu and another where you
associate a menu item with an object. In the latter it will show up on any
popup menu that appears when you have a specific object selected.

It sounds like your problem is solved, but if you want to write a plugin
anyways, you would use the latter mode where you would hook the Run JUnit
action to an IFile (you could probably add it to a Java object, but I don't
know what the name of the interface is off the top of my head. It has some
weird name like org.eclipse.jdt.core.IPackageFragment, or
org.eclipse.jdt.core.ICompilationUnit or something. You can try those.)
and then add a filter such as *Test.java so that it only shows up when you
select a file with that naming convention. Here is a little plugin.xml
exerpt:

<extension point="org.eclipse.ui.popupMenus">
<objectContribution
id="org.eclipse.ui.articles.action.contribution.popup.object"
objectClass="org.eclipse.core.resources.IFile"
nameFilter="*Test.java">
<filter
name="projectNature"
value="org.eclipse.jdt.core.javanature">
</filter>
<action
id="com.myCompany.ui.myPlugin.actions.JUnitAction"
label="Run JUnit Test..."
icon="icons/junit.gif"
menubarPath="additions"
class="com.myCompany.ui.myPlugin.actions.JUnitAction">
</action>
</objectContribution>
</extension>

Actually, you may just want to dig through eclipse code to find the JUnit
action that already exists and plug that straight into the action portion
of your objectContribution tag.

Code examples and information are based off the article:
http://www.eclipse.org/articles/index.html so you may want to reference
that for more information. Specifically I was looking at Example 3.

-Phil
